title: Lord of the Rings fans want to build a £1.85bn replica of Minas Tirith
text:
26 shares 1

comments
Diehard fans of the Lord of the Rings trilogy may one day be able to holiday or even live in a real-life version of Minas Tirith – and they won’t have to travel to Middle Earth to get there.
A group of devotees of the wildly popular book and film series has started an ambitious campaign to raise £1.85bn ($2.8bn) to build a full-scale replica of the fictional walled city – complete with residences and shops – somewhere in southern England.
While it may seem like an incredibly unlikely goal, the group behind the 60-day Indiegogo campaign is confident it can reach its target by offering luxury penthouses or one-bedroom flats in exchange for individual donations of up to £1.72million ($2.68million).
Minas Tirith is a fictional walled city featured in the Lord of the Rings book and film series
Jonathan Wilson, the Lord of the Rings fan who created the Indiegogo page, said a team of architects and structural engineers are behind the plans to create a ‘beautiful, inspirational and fully-functional replica of [film director] Peter Jackson’s depiction of Minas Tirith’.
He said their aim is to create ‘the most remarkable tourist attraction on the planet’ and a ‘wonderfully unique place to live and work’.
Mr Wilson, 24, from Worcester, wrote on the Indiegogo page: ‘We're fully aware of the scale of our ambition, but we hope you realise just how special this project could be.’
So far the group has raised almost £17,000 ($26,500) – far less than one per cent of its goal – from 502 people, with 48 days to go until the Indiegogo page expires. They are on pace to raise £68,000 ($106,000), unless donations pick up.

Dramatic moment British holidaymaker was airlifted from Fred... 26 shares Incentives are being dangled in front of prospective donors, with the top offer being a luxury four-bedroom penthouse ‘with the best views’ and a 100-year lease in exchange for a £1.72million ($2.68million) contribution.
A £400,000 ($623,000) donation guarantees a one-bedroom flat should the project reach its fundraising goal and move forward.
For £100,000 ($156,000), donors can become a lord or lady of the city, with exclusive access to all areas except private residences, use of horse-drawn carriages and a seat on the executive committee.
For those who don’t have a giant chunk of change to give, the ‘Realise Minas Tirith’ project’s official Twitter account will follow anyone who gives £3 ($4.65).
A group of friends came up with the idea after watching the films (pictured: Gandalf, portrayed by Ian McKellen)
The group said the vast majority of the £1.85bn ($2.8bn) budget would be earmarked for building costs, including £1.4bn ($2.1bn) for material and £188million ($293million) for labour.
Remaining cash would be used to pay off maintenance and public services until 2053.
If the group doesn’t reach its goal, it said all pledges will be cancelled and donors will not be charged.
Mr Wilson came up with the idea during a Lord of the Rings marathon with friends.
He said: ‘When it finished we enthused about the idea of crowdfunding real-life locations from the films. We settled on Minas Tirith, as we felt it represented the most realistic and sustainable project.
‘Obviously we realise that we are venturing into unchartered territory as far as crowdfunding is concerned, but we’ve been blown away by the amount of interest that our project has generated. The positive reaction to the campaign gives me a faint hope that we can reach our target.’
‘I think it’s perfectly reasonable for people to doubt our prospects of success. What I don’t agree with are the people who say there are more worthwhile projects to which we should be devoting our time.
‘That’s a principle that, if you choose to, you can apply to virtually any aspect of life. We’re trying to achieve something that will be ground-breaking, unique and a real boost to both the local and national economy.’
